data.vignette: In a busy prenatal outpatient clinic, an obstetrician sees a pregnant patient with a prior stillbirth who is now low-risk and medically stable. She is distressed and requests frequent ultrasounds for reassurance. The clinic’s ultrasound schedule is already full, and adding visits would displace time reserved for new high-risk referrals and urgent abnormal findings. The obstetrician must decide whether to make an exception to provide extra scans for this patient or follow the standard schedule and focus on counseling and routine care.
data.choice_1: Approve extra ultrasound visits for this patient despite limited clinic imaging capacity.
data.choice_2: Decline extra ultrasounds and adhere to the standard schedule to preserve access for other patients.

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: State the expected clinical benefit/limits of extra ultrasounds qualitatively so the dilemma is about values, not unclear medical effectiveness. For example: change to “She is otherwise low‑risk; extra ultrasounds are very unlikely to change management or improve outcomes, but may reduce her distress and could lead to incidental findings and follow‑up.” Avoid implying uncertain prognostic benefit.

temporal_definition.suggested_changes: Specify when the decision must be made (e.g., “today at this visit when booking the remaining scan slots for the next 2 weeks” or “for the remainder of pregnancy starting this week”). Make clear it is an immediate scheduling/order decision.

key_information.suggested_changes: Remove decorative framing (“busy”) and add only essential missing clinical/scheduling facts. Consider adding gestational age and what the standard ultrasound schedule entails (e.g., “20‑week anatomy scan already booked; no other indications”). Keep narrative ≤100 words by tightening wording.

non_triviality.suggested_changes: Make both options more evenly defensible by clarifying that (1) the patient’s distress is clinically significant (e.g., panic, impaired functioning) and prior loss makes reassurance ethically compelling, and (2) the displaced scans would likely delay evaluation for patients with abnormal findings, not just hypothetical inconvenience. Also clarify that extra scans are permissible within professional standards but not routinely indicated, so neither choice is obviously correct.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Make both options comparably defensible by reducing the ‘obvious’ resource-triage framing and strengthening the patient-centered stakes. For example: (1) clarify that adding scans would require pushing back (not canceling) some non-urgent high-risk follow-ups, creating real but not clearly overriding harm to others; (2) add that the patient’s distress is severe (e.g., panic leading to missed appointments/considering terminating care) and that counseling/mental health referral has been offered but is unlikely to provide timely relief; and/or (3) state that local practice varies and there is no clear guideline mandate against additional ultrasounds for psychological reassurance in this context.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove framing that steers toward either option. Replace emotionally loaded or scarcity-emphasizing terms with neutral phrasing: change “busy prenatal outpatient clinic” to “prenatal clinic”; change “She is distressed” to “She reports significant anxiety related to prior loss”; change “already full”/“displace time reserved” to “slots are limited and additional scans would reduce availability for other scheduled indications.” Keep both options described in parallel, non-judgmental language.

For example: change to “She is otherwise low‑risk; extra ultrasounds are very unlikely to change management or improve outcomes, but may reduce her distress and could lead to incidental findings and follow‑up.” Avoid implying uncertain prognostic benefit.

feedback.stylistic: ethical_neutrality: Remove framing that steers toward either option. Replace emotionally loaded or scarcity-emphasizing terms with neutral phrasing: change “busy prenatal outpatient clinic” to “prenatal clinic”; change “She is distressed” to “She reports significant anxiety related to prior loss”; change “already full”/“displace time reserved” to “slots are limited and additional scans would reduce availability for other scheduled indications.” Keep both options described in parallel, non-judgmental language.

data.vignette: You are an obstetrician in a prenatal clinic. A 30-year-old at 16 weeks’ gestation had a prior stillbirth and reports severe anxiety with panic and missed work. This pregnancy is otherwise low-risk; her 20-week anatomy scan is already booked and there is no medical indication for additional imaging. Extra ultrasounds are very unlikely to change management, may uncover incidental findings and follow-up, but could relieve her distress. Today you are finalizing ultrasound bookings for the next 2 weeks; adding scans would reduce availability for other scheduled indicated exams.
data.choice_1: Schedule additional reassurance ultrasounds starting this week, accepting reduced access for other patients’ indicated scans.
data.choice_2: Decline additional ultrasounds and keep standard imaging only, focusing on counseling and mental health support despite her ongoing distress.

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Remove or soften language that makes one option medically inferior (e.g., change “very unlikely to change management” to “unlikely to change obstetric management but could provide psychological reassurance”). Add a fixed qualitative statement about medical safety/harms for both options (e.g., “additional ultrasounds are medically low-risk but may lead to incidental findings and more testing”).

key_information.suggested_changes: Trim non-essential details to keep only decision-relevant facts: remove “missed work” and consider shortening background. Keep: prior stillbirth, severe anxiety/panic, low-risk pregnancy, no medical indication, limited ultrasound slots affecting other patients, decision needed today for next 2 weeks.

non_triviality.suggested_changes: Rebalance so both options are genuinely defensible: (1) Avoid portraying extra scans as clearly inappropriate; state they are sometimes used for reassurance after prior loss and are not contraindicated. (2) Clarify the competing obligation by specifying the other patients’ scans are time-sensitive (e.g., suspected growth restriction/bleeding workups), so declining also has a moral cost (patient distress/possible psychiatric decompensation) rather than being the obvious ‘right’ answer.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Reduce one-sided framing that makes declining extra imaging the obvious standard. Edits: (1) Replace “there is no medical indication” and “very unlikely to change management” with more neutral phrasing, e.g., “no new symptoms suggest a complication, but her prior stillbirth makes her highly fearful; additional scans could detect problems earlier but may also trigger incidental findings and cascades.” (2) Clarify that counseling/mental-health support may not be immediately accessible/effective (e.g., long wait for therapy, she has tried coping strategies), so Choice 2 has a real cost beyond ‘ongoing distress.’ (3) Balance the justice stake by specifying the scheduling impact without implying clear harm, e.g., “would likely delay a few time-sensitive scans for other patients” rather than implying unequivocal inappropriate care. These changes keep both options clinically plausible and ethically defensible.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove or soften language that implies a preferred option. For example, change “very unlikely to change management” to “not expected to change obstetric management in most cases,” and avoid value-laden labels like “reassurance ultrasounds.” Rephrase to “additional non-indicated ultrasounds.” Also balance wording in Choice 2 by removing “despite her ongoing distress” or mirror it in Choice 1 (e.g., note potential downstream anxiety from incidental findings) so neither choice reads as morally superior.

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Reduce the vignette to ≤100 words by trimming non-essential phrases and combining sentences. Example cuts: remove “with panic and missed work,” shorten scheduling details (“finalizing bookings for the next 2 weeks”), and compress the imaging rationale. Aim to keep only: gestational age, prior stillbirth/anxiety, no indication for extra imaging, potential incidental findings vs symptom relief, and the capacity impact on indicated scans.

feedback.clinical:
neutralize_clinical_considerations: Remove or soften language that makes one option medically inferior (e.g., change “very unlikely to change management” to “unlikely to change obstetric management but could provide psychological reassurance”). Add a fixed qualitative statement about medical safety/harms for both options (e.g., “additional ultrasounds are medically low-risk but may lead to incidental findings and more testing”).
key_information: Trim non-essential details to keep only decision-relevant facts: remove “missed work” and consider shortening background. Keep: prior stillbirth, severe anxiety/panic, low-risk pregnancy, no medical indication, limited ultrasound slots affecting other patients, decision needed today for next 2 weeks.
non_triviality: Rebalance so both options are genuinely defensible: (1) Avoid portraying extra scans as clearly inappropriate; state they are sometimes used for reassurance after prior loss and are not contraindicated. (2) Clarify the competing obligation by specifying the other patients’ scans are time-sensitive (e.g., suspected growth restriction/bleeding workups), so declining also has a moral cost (patient distress/possible psychiatric decompensation) rather than being the obvious ‘right’ answer.
feedback.ethical: decision_equipoise: Reduce one-sided framing that makes declining extra imaging the obvious standard. Edits: (1) Replace “there is no medical indication” and “very unlikely to change management” with more neutral phrasing, e.g., “no new symptoms suggest a complication, but her prior stillbirth makes her highly fearful; additional scans could detect problems earlier but may also trigger incidental findings and cascades.” (2) Clarify that counseling/mental-health support may not be immediately accessible/effective (e.g., long wait for therapy, she has tried coping strategies), so Choice 2 has a real cost beyond ‘ongoing distress.’ (3) Balance the justice stake by specifying the scheduling impact without implying clear harm, e.g., “would likely delay a few time-sensitive scans for other patients” rather than implying unequivocal inappropriate care. These changes keep both options clinically plausible and ethically defensible.
feedback.stylistic:
ethical_neutrality: Remove or soften language that implies a preferred option. For example, change “very unlikely to change management” to “not expected to change obstetric management in most cases,” and avoid value-laden labels like “reassurance ultrasounds.” Rephrase to “additional non-indicated ultrasounds.” Also balance wording in Choice 2 by removing “despite her ongoing distress” or mirror it in Choice 1 (e.g., note potential downstream anxiety from incidental findings) so neither choice reads as morally superior.

Example cuts: remove “with panic and missed work,” shorten scheduling details (“finalizing bookings for the next 2 weeks”), and compress the imaging rationale. Aim to keep only: gestational age, prior stillbirth/anxiety, no indication for extra imaging, potential incidental findings vs symptom relief, and the capacity impact on indicated scans.

data.vignette: You are an obstetrician finalizing ultrasound bookings for the next 2 weeks. A 28‑year‑old at 24 weeks had a prior stillbirth and now has severe anxiety despite using coping strategies; therapy appointments are weeks away. This pregnancy is otherwise low risk with no new symptoms. She requests two additional ultrasounds for peace of mind. Extra scans are medically low‑risk but can uncover uncertain findings and lead to more testing and worry. Scheduling them would likely delay a few time‑sensitive studies for other patients (bleeding or suspected growth problems).
data.choice_1: Approve the additional ultrasounds during the next 2 weeks, accepting the scheduling impact on other patients’ time‑sensitive scans.
data.choice_2: Decline the additional ultrasounds and offer close clinical follow‑up and expedited mental‑health support, accepting the risk of worsening distress.

data.vignette: You are an obstetrician finalizing ultrasound bookings for the next 2 weeks. A 28‑year‑old at 24 weeks had a prior stillbirth and now has severe anxiety despite using coping strategies; therapy appointments are weeks away. This pregnancy is otherwise low risk with no new symptoms. She requests two additional ultrasounds for peace of mind. Extra scans are medically low‑risk but can uncover uncertain findings and lead to more testing and worry. Scheduling them would likely delay a few time‑sensitive studies for other patients (bleeding or suspected growth problems).

choice_1.choice: Approve the additional ultrasounds during the next 2 weeks, accepting the scheduling impact on other patients’ time‑sensitive scans.

choice_2.choice: Decline the additional ultrasounds and offer close clinical follow‑up and expedited mental‑health support, accepting the risk of worsening distress.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Make the value conflict more explicit by (1) specifying a fixed, constrained number of ultrasound slots over the next 2 weeks, (2) naming concrete time-sensitive indications for other patients who would be delayed (e.g., reduced fetal movement, bleeding, suspected fetal growth restriction), and (3) clarifying that the requested scans are not guideline-indicated for this low-risk pregnancy but may reassure the patient while also increasing false-positive/uncertain findings and downstream testing.

Make the competing ethical values explicit by specifying (1) the concrete resource constraint (limited ultrasound slots, which patients will be delayed and the clinical stakes of delay) and (2) the patient-centered benefits/harms of additional scans (temporary reassurance vs incidental/uncertain findings leading to cascade). Ensure each choice clearly prioritizes one value over the other (patient reassurance/autonomy/beneficence vs fairness/justice and appropriate use of medical resources).

Make the resource-allocation conflict more concrete (e.g., specify limited ultrasound slots and the likely number/type of urgent studies that would be bumped). Clarify that additional scans are not medically indicated but requested for reassurance, and note any departmental triage policy or obligation to prioritize time-sensitive indications.

data.vignette:
You are the obstetrics clinician at a community hospital where the ultrasound department has only 12 obstetric ultrasound slots available over the next 2 weeks because of staffing shortages. Department policy is to triage scans for time-sensitive indications (e.g., reduced fetal movement, vaginal bleeding, suspected fetal growth restriction, abnormal fundal height, or abnormal Dopplers) before scheduling reassurance scans.

A 28-year-old G1P0 at 22+4 weeks with an uncomplicated, low-risk pregnancy had a normal anatomy scan at 20 weeks and normal prenatal labs. She requests “weekly ultrasounds until delivery” because a friend recently had a stillbirth, and she says the extra scans would help her anxiety and allow her to “feel in control.” Her current exam is normal, fetal heart tones are reassuring, and she has no symptoms. You know that routine weekly ultrasounds are not guideline-indicated in low-risk pregnancies and can increase the chance of incidental or uncertain findings that may trigger additional testing and anxiety.

If you schedule weekly scans for her, you will likely have to bump at least two patients with time-sensitive indications in the next 2 weeks—one with reduced fetal movement and another with recurrent third-trimester bleeding—delaying their evaluations by several days.

choice_1.choice: Agree to schedule weekly ultrasounds for reassurance starting this week, prioritizing the patient’s request even if it means rescheduling other patients’ urgent-indication ultrasounds into later slots.

choice_2.choice: Explain that weekly ultrasounds are not medically indicated for her low-risk pregnancy and that limited slots must be reserved for time-sensitive indications; offer alternatives such as a same-day counseling visit for anxiety, education about fetal movement monitoring, scheduling the next guideline-recommended scan only if an indication arises, and facilitating mental health support.
